title: How to Make Raspberry Jam (Freezer Method)

steps.headline: Measure fruit and sugar into a large bowl.
Combine 3/4 cup water and Sure-Jell into small pan.
Boil for 1 minute, stirring constantly.
steps.description: Add to fruit mixture and stir for approximately 3 minutes.

steps.headline: Put into sterilized jars or plastic containers.
steps.description: Cover. Leave room for expansion when freezing.

steps.headline: Let set at room temperature for 24 hours.
Label and date the jars.
steps.description: Pop the jars into the freezer and let freeze.

steps.headline: Thaw in the refrigerator prior to eating.
steps.description: The frozen jam should stay good for up to a year.

steps.headline: Prepare the raspberries.
steps.description: Give them a very gentle rinse by dipping them into cold water while in a colander.

steps.headline: Tip into a mixing bowl.
steps.description: Mash with a potato masher or a muddle.

steps.headline: Measure the 8 cups needed for this recipe.
Add 7 cups of sugar to a preserving pot or large heavy-based saucepan.
steps.description: Add the Sure-Jell (or other brand) pectin too. Stir to combine well.

steps.headline: Turn the stove hotplate onto medium-high heat.
steps.description: Cook until it starts to boil, stirring constantly. When it starts to boil, cook for 1 minute exactly (no more).

steps.headline: Remove from the heat immediately.
steps.description: Add the crushed raspberries and stir for 1 minute.

steps.headline: Pour into the sterilized jars.
steps.description: Seal tightly. Let stand for 24 hours. During this time the jam will set. Do not fill right to the top; leave space for expansion during freezing.

steps.headline: Label and date the jars.
steps.description: Pop the jars into the freezer and let freeze.

steps.headline: Thaw in the refrigerator prior to eating.
steps.description: The frozen jam should stay good for up to a year.

text: Smaller amount Measure fruit and sugar into a large bowl.  Mix well. Let set 10 minutes to macerate. Combine 3/4 cup water and Sure-Jell into small pan.  Boil for 1 minute, stirring constantly. Add to fruit mixture and stir for approximately 3 minutes. Put into sterilized jars or plastic containers. Cover. Leave room for expansion when freezing. Let set at room temperature for 24 hours.  Label and date the jars. Pop the jars into the freezer and let freeze. Thaw in the refrigerator prior to eating. The frozen jam should stay good for up to a year. Larger amount Prepare the raspberries. Give them a very gentle rinse by dipping them into cold water while in a colander. Tip into a mixing bowl. Mash with a potato masher or a muddle. Measure the 8 cups needed for this recipe.  Add 7 cups of sugar to a preserving pot or large heavy-based saucepan. Add the Sure-Jell (or other brand) pectin too. Stir to combine well. Add 2 cups of water. Stir through. Turn the stove hotplate onto medium-high heat. Cook until it starts to boil, stirring constantly. When it starts to boil, cook for 1 minute exactly (no more). Remove from the heat immediately. Add the crushed raspberries and stir for 1 minute. Pour into the sterilized jars. Seal tightly. Let stand for 24 hours. During this time the jam will set. Do not fill right to the top; leave space for expansion during freezing. Label and date the jars. Pop the jars into the freezer and let freeze. Thaw in the refrigerator prior to eating. The frozen jam should stay good for up to a year.
